content: "http://www.cnn.com/2009/POLITICS/04/22/martin.miss.california/index.html" A lot of folks are always saying they like to keep it real, that they want authenticity and straight talk. Yet when someone actually does it, there is hell to pay. Welcome to the world of Miss California, Carrie Prejean, who, since she answered a question regarding same-sex marriage in Sunday's Miss USA pageant, has been savagely attacked by those who oppose what she had to say. Leading the burn-her-at-the-stake parade is media opportunist Perez Hilton, the self-described gossip queen, and the individual who kick-started this controversy by asking the initial question as to whether the issue of same-sex marriage should be left up to the states. It seems that Hilton, who is gay, was none too pleased that Prejean chose to actually give her personal opinion on the issue, and ripped her on his blog after the show, using crude obscenities as he continued to attack her at every turn on his media blitz. Hey, Hilton, from a real journalist to a wanna-be who traffics in gossip: Never ask a question if you're unprepared for the answer! Frankly, this whole story is pretty stupid. Isn't the whole point of asking a question to get someone's true feelings, rather than the plastic and superficial answers we are all used to receiving? Sure, Prejean could have gone the safe route and given one of those answers that reveal nothing and is hard to decipher -- you know, the ones politicians give all the time -- but no! She actually gave her real opinion, and is now being torn to shreds for it. She opposes same-sex marriage. OK, fine. So what if she had said, "Hey, I'm in full support of same-sex marriage." Would she now be celebrated on gay-focused blogs, magazines and Web sites? Would her detractors actually be saying how open she is and that she's a great person? Same-sex marriage is undoubtedly a hot button issue. And being from California, the site of Proposition 8, the ballot initiative that voters approved outlawing same-sex marriage, Prejean has surely had to hear the debate go back and forth. But her remark isn't outside the mainstream. A CNN/Opinion Research Corp. poll shows that 55 percent of Americans are against same-sex marriage, and Proposition 8 did pass in her state 52-48 percent. What's interesting about this is that many of the same folks who are slamming her for her remark voted for President Obama and Vice President Joe Biden, who both have the same belief: that marriage should be between a man and a woman. Even Secretary of State Hillary Clinton made it clear that she has the same view, and it was her husband, President Bill Clinton, who signed the In Defense of Marriage Act, the federal law that forbids states from having to recognize gay marriage in other states. In other words, four of the biggest liberals in the country have the same belief as Prejean, but a beauty pageant winner is being torn to shreds. Hello, hypocrisy! Those who criticize Prejean have the same right as she does to express their viewpoints. But enough with all the political correctness, where someone says she should have danced around the issue, smiled and move on. At the end of the day, we all have to be true to ourselves. Whether it's a gay gossip writer who favors same-sex marriage or a heterosexual woman who is against same-sex marriage. The day we condemn folks for speaking honestly is the day we become a bland society. Now, I have no issue with gay marriage. If it passes, I just don't care. I live in a gay marriage state and I don't care. However, I respect the beliefs of other, both for and against. What strikes me about this whole situation is how much vitrol the "liberal" and "open minded" crowd show toward someone who disagrees with them. This animosity and pure hatred from those that are supposed to be the keepers of "accept that which is different" group of people is really just pure hypocrisy.

content: So if I say I dislike group X because a book makes some obscure reference to the "abomination" of that group and some other people have (mis)interpreted the words in that book for centuries then I'm right and anyone who says differently is a biased/bigoted/hatemonger? The pageant contestants "right" to her opinion is somehow more correct then the pageant judges "right" to his opinion? Because one is more vociferous in their "rightness" it makes that person more wrong then the other? Admittedly, the one being the most vocal is only making their position more tenuous. Seems that to make a better case for his position, Hilton should have praised her for her convictions....Duh. Of all escape mechanisms, Death is the most efficient. ~~ H.L. Mencken
reply: So if I say I dislike group X because a book makes some obscure reference to the "abomination" of that group and some other people have (mis)interpreted the words in that book for centuries then I'm right and anyone who says differently is a biased/bigoted/hatemonger? You can back off the right-wing paranoia any old time now. Perez Hilton is your typical gay liberal. Just like Dick Cheney or Rush Limbaugh are your typical conservative I suppose... Either way, the national organization for women and other liberal organizations condemned and demanded an apology from Ultimate Fighting Championship chairman Dana White for his comments...they were considered sexist. Yet....When a liberal uses the same exact words as Mr.White did.....SILENCE... Thats my point...and te OP's point...liberal BS.
reply: Summary of Statement by California NOW quote: So here's my little three-part note to everyone out there: Dear bigots, please start recognizing the inherent human worth of every individual, even those you don't like or understand. Dear oppressed minority group members, please stop using oppressive language about members of other oppressed minority groups. Dear members of majority religious groups, please stop acting like you're part of the oppressed minority. Now of course is an organisation with an agenda. And that agenda is quite limited. Any statement from NOW represnts NOW, not Liberals, not the political left. To quote a great Liberal Spokesperson, who actually posts here: Perez IS a moron. Dave

title: Liberal hypocrisy

content: "http://www.cnn.com/2009/POLITICS/04/22/martin.miss.california/index.html" A lot of folks are always saying they like to keep it real, that they want authenticity and straight talk. Yet when someone actually does it, there is hell to pay. Welcome to the world of Miss California, Carrie Prejean, who, since she answered a question regarding same-sex marriage in Sunday's Miss USA pageant, has been savagely attacked by those who oppose what she had to say. Leading the burn-her-at-the-stake parade is media opportunist Perez Hilton, the self-described gossip queen, and the individual who kick-started this controversy by asking the initial question as to whether the issue of same-sex marriage should be left up to the states. It seems that Hilton, who is gay, was none too pleased that Prejean chose to actually give her personal opinion on the issue, and ripped her on his blog after the show, using crude obscenities as he continued to attack her at every turn on his media blitz. Hey, Hilton, from a real journalist to a wanna-be who traffics in gossip: Never ask a question if you're unprepared for the answer! Frankly, this whole story is pretty stupid. Isn't the whole point of asking a question to get someone's true feelings, rather than the plastic and superficial answers we are all used to receiving? Sure, Prejean could have gone the safe route and given one of those answers that reveal nothing and is hard to decipher -- you know, the ones politicians give all the time -- but no! She actually gave her real opinion, and is now being torn to shreds for it. She opposes same-sex marriage. OK, fine. So what if she had said, "Hey, I'm in full support of same-sex marriage." Would she now be celebrated on gay-focused blogs, magazines and Web sites? Would her detractors actually be saying how open she is and that she's a great person? Same-sex marriage is undoubtedly a hot button issue. And being from California, the site of Proposition 8, the ballot initiative that voters approved outlawing same-sex marriage, Prejean has surely had to hear the debate go back and forth. But her remark isn't outside the mainstream. A CNN/Opinion Research Corp. poll shows that 55 percent of Americans are against same-sex marriage, and Proposition 8 did pass in her state 52-48 percent. What's interesting about this is that many of the same folks who are slamming her for her remark voted for President Obama and Vice President Joe Biden, who both have the same belief: that marriage should be between a man and a woman. Even Secretary of State Hillary Clinton made it clear that she has the same view, and it was her husband, President Bill Clinton, who signed the In Defense of Marriage Act, the federal law that forbids states from having to recognize gay marriage in other states. In other words, four of the biggest liberals in the country have the same belief as Prejean, but a beauty pageant winner is being torn to shreds. Hello, hypocrisy! Those who criticize Prejean have the same right as she does to express their viewpoints. But enough with all the political correctness, where someone says she should have danced around the issue, smiled and move on. At the end of the day, we all have to be true to ourselves. Whether it's a gay gossip writer who favors same-sex marriage or a heterosexual woman who is against same-sex marriage. The day we condemn folks for speaking honestly is the day we become a bland society. Now, I have no issue with gay marriage. If it passes, I just don't care. I live in a gay marriage state and I don't care. However, I respect the beliefs of other, both for and against. What strikes me about this whole situation is how much vitrol the "liberal" and "open minded" crowd show toward someone who disagrees with them. This animosity and pure hatred from those that are supposed to be the keepers of "accept that which is different" group of people is really just pure hypocrisy.

content: So if I say I dislike group X because a book makes some obscure reference to the "abomination" of that group and some other people have (mis)interpreted the words in that book for centuries then I'm right and anyone who says differently is a biased/bigoted/hatemonger? The pageant contestants "right" to her opinion is somehow more correct then the pageant judges "right" to his opinion? Because one is more vociferous in their "rightness" it makes that person more wrong then the other? Admittedly, the one being the most vocal is only making their position more tenuous. Seems that to make a better case for his position, Hilton should have praised her for her convictions....Duh. Of all escape mechanisms, Death is the most efficient. ~~ H.L. Mencken

You claim "Its perfectly okay for Liberal darling and spokesman Perez Hilton to call Miss California a "B*TCH" and a "C*nt" for not supporting same-sex marriage"...BS. All of the "liberals" on this board have condemned this jerk, not only for his demeaning language toward this young woman, but for bringing his political agenda into the “beauty contest”. You can back off the right-wing paranoia any old time now. Perez Hilton is your typical gay liberal. Just like Dick Cheney or Rush Limbaugh are your typical conservative I suppose... Either way, the national organization for women and other liberal organizations condemned and demanded an apology from Ultimate Fighting Championship chairman Dana White for his comments...they were considered sexist. Yet....When a liberal uses the same exact words as Mr.White did.....SILENCE... Thats my point...and te OP's point...liberal BS. Summary of Statement by California NOW quote: So here's my little three-part note to everyone out there: Dear bigots, please start recognizing the inherent human worth of every individual, even those you don't like or understand. Dear oppressed minority group members, please stop using oppressive language about members of other oppressed minority groups. Dear members of majority religious groups, please stop acting like you're part of the oppressed minority. Now of course is an organisation with an agenda. And that agenda is quite limited. Any statement from NOW represnts NOW, not Liberals, not the political left. To quote a great Liberal Spokesperson, who actually posts here: Perez IS a moron. Dave

Either way, the national organization for women and other liberal organizations condemned and demanded an apology from Ultimate Fighting Championship chairman Dana White for his comments...they were considered sexist. Yet....When a liberal uses the same exact words as Mr.White did.....SILENCE... Thats my point...and te OP's point...liberal BS.
reply: Summary of Statement by California NOW quote: So here's my little three-part note to everyone out there: Dear bigots, please start recognizing the inherent human worth of every individual, even those you don't like or understand. Dear oppressed minority group members, please stop using oppressive language about members of other oppressed minority groups. Dear members of majority religious groups, please stop acting like you're part of the oppressed minority. Now of course is an organisation with an agenda. And that agenda is quite limited. Any statement from NOW represnts NOW, not Liberals, not the political left. To quote a great Liberal Spokesperson, who actually posts here: Perez IS a moron. Dave
title: Liberal hypocrisy

content: quote: Originally posted by KJ1110: It's a frakkin' Beauty Pagent fer crissakes! Who the heck cares! It means absolutely nothing, whoever wins! Sheesh! I think this nation has more important concerns that a bunch of whiney primadonnas who probably will never accomplish anything of greater import than this meaningless contest! Get a life! Glad someone said it, because I didn't even want to have to type it out
